docs.lead_paragraph: Decoding the genome has led to stunning advances in scientific knowledge but has done relatively little to improve medical treatments or human health.

docs.lead_paragraph: Can someone infected with herpes continue to have sex without giving it to their partner? Do cold sores, which are almost always caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), protect against genital herpes caused by herpes simplex virus type 2? Can someone be infected with both types of herpes viruses?
docs.abstract: About 10 percent of adults in the United States have both herpes simplex virus type 1 and type 2. Using condoms is one way to reduce exposure.
docs.snippet: About 10 percent of adults in the United States have both herpes simplex virus type 1 and type 2. Using condoms is one way to reduce exposure.

docs.lead_paragraph: In our recent exchange about a soda tax, Greg Mankiw raised an important question: Do the estimates of the medical costs of obesity take into account the fact that obese people don't live as long on average?
docs.abstract: More on the debate about obesity, medical costs and a soda tax.

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Is the Internet making teenagers do more dumb things than ever? Some child specialists worry that it is. Teenagers have always been prone to taking foolish risks (thanks partly to the brain's prefrontal cortex, which governs decision-making and is still developing in adolescence). But with the rise of sites like YouTube and Facebook, these experts say, teenagers now face virtual peer pressure to emulate all kinds of dangerous stunts and dares, and post them online.

headline.main: Stupid Teenage Tricks, For a Virtual Audience

docs.abstract: Teenagers, who have always been prone to take unnecessary risks, may be flexing their foolishness even more now that YouTube and other Web sites provide way to show off their stunts; researchers suggest that Internet could be used to warn teens of dangers; Dr Megan A Moreno, University of Wisconsin adolescent medicine specialist, leads study using MySpace persona called Dr Meg; research, which is published in Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine, finds that teens given advice about their Internet content are twice as likely to remove references to sex or substance use than those not advised; photo (M)
